age_8_12.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to a child (8-12 years old). Use simple words like you're explaining to a 4th grader. Make it fun and relatable to school, sports teams, or clubs. Be very encouraging!

vocabulary_replacements.360-degree feedback: asking everyone what you're good at
vocabulary_replacements.talent development: helping people get better at their jobs

age_13_15.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to a teenager (13-15 years old). Use clear language but not childish. Connect ideas to school projects, student government, or team sports. Explain business terms when you use them.

vocabulary_replacements.360-degree feedback: feedback from all directions - your teacher, classmates, and teammates

age_16_18.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to a high school student (16-18 years old). Use professional language but add context for unfamiliar business concepts. Treat them seriously as emerging professionals.

vocabulary_replacements.inter-brand mobility: moving between different teams or departments to gain experience
vocabulary_replacements.360-degree feedback: comprehensive feedback from manager, peers, and team members

age_19_25.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to a college student or early-career professional (19-25 years old). Use full professional vocabulary but explain luxury industry jargon. Relate concepts to internships, entry-level roles, and career development. Frame everything as building their professional foundation.

vocabulary_replacements.inter-brand mobility: inter-brand mobility (moving between brand teams - similar to rotational programs at companies like GE or Unilever where you build diverse experience)
vocabulary_replacements.360-degree feedback: 360-degree feedback (comprehensive performance input from your manager, peers, and direct reports - commonly used for high-potential professionals)

vocabulary_replacements.cascade: cascade (systematically roll out across the organization - a key change management skill)
vocabulary_replacements.stakeholder: stakeholder (anyone impacted by or invested in the outcome - important for managing up and across)
vocabulary_replacements.behavioral indicators: behavioral indicators (specific, observable actions that demonstrate a competency - what you'd put on a resume or discuss in interviews)
vocabulary_replacements.talent pipeline: talent pipeline (identifying and developing future leaders - how companies build internal succession)
vocabulary_replacements.succession planning: succession planning (preparing people for future leadership roles)

career_framing.leadership_development: Building your professional toolkit for future roles
career_framing.competencies: Skills that will serve you throughout your career
career_framing.feedback: Critical for early-career growth and advancement

age_8_12.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to a child (8-12 years old). Explain business concepts like you would to a young team captain. Use simple words and relate to teams, goals, and winning.

age_13_15.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to a teenager (13-15 years old). Explain business strategy clearly. Use examples from sports teams, school clubs, or student organizations.

vocabulary_replacements.M&A: M&A (mergers and acquisitions - buying and integrating other companies)

vocabulary_replacements.brand equity: brand equity (the commercial value and customer perception of a brand)

career_framing.strategy: Think about this like a case study - similar to what you'd analyze in business school

age_26_plus.system_prompt_addon: IMPORTANT: You are talking to an experienced executive peer (26+ years old). Use full C-suite vocabulary. Be direct and strategic. Expect sophisticated business thinking.

vocabulary_replacements.change management: change management (helping people adapt to new processes - the human side of implementation that they don't teach in school)
vocabulary_replacements.stakeholder management: stakeholder management (keeping everyone informed and on board - critical for your success in any HR role)
vocabulary_replacements.train-the-trainer: train-the-trainer (teaching others to teach - how you scale without being everywhere at once)
